001package squidpony.squidgrid.mapping;
002
003import squidpony.squidmath.LightRNG;
004import squidpony.squidmath.PerlinNoise;
005import squidpony.squidmath.RNG;
006
007import java.awt.Point;
008
009/**
010 * A static class that can be used to modify the char[][] dungeons that other generators produce.
011 * Includes various utilities for random floor-finding, but also provides ways to take dungeons that use '#'
012 * for walls and make a copy that uses unicode box drawing characters.
013 * @see squidpony.squidgrid.mapping.DungeonGenerator
014 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 4/1/2015.
015 * @author Tommy Ettinger - https://github.com/tommyettinger
016 */
017public class DungeonUtility {
018    /**
019     * The random number generator that will be used for all methods in this class with a random component.
020     */
021    public static RNG rng = new RNG(new LightRNG());
022    /**
023     * Finds a random java.awt.Point where the x and y match up to a [x][y] location on map that has '.' as a value.
024     * Uses this class' rng field for pseudo-random number generation.
025     * @param map
026     * @return a Point that corresponds to a '.' in map, or null if a '.' cannot be found or if map is too small.
027     */
028    public static Point randomFloor(char[][] map)
029    {
030        int width = map.length;
031        int height = map[0].length;
032        if(width < 3 || height < 3)
033            return null;
034        Point pt = new Point(rng.nextInt(width), rng.nextInt(height));
035        for(int i = 0; i < 20; i++)
036        {
037            if(map[pt.x][pt.y] == '.')
038            {
039                return pt;
040            }
041            else
042            {
043                pt.x = rng.nextInt(width);
044                pt.y = rng.nextInt(height);
045            }
046        }
047        pt.x = 1;
048        pt.y = 1;
049        if(map[pt.x][pt.y] == '.')
050            return pt;
051
052        while(map[pt.x][pt.y] != '.')
053        {
054            pt.x += 1;
055            if(pt.x >= width - 1)
056            {
057                pt.x = 1;
058                pt.y += 1;
059            }
060            if(pt.y >= height - 1)
061                return null;
062        }
063        return pt;
064    }
065
066    /**
067     * Gets a random Point that is adjacent to start, validating whether the position can exist on the given map.
068     * Adjacency defaults to four-way cardinal directions unless eightWay is true, in which case it uses Chebyshev.
069     * This can step into walls, and should NOT be used for movement.  It is meant for things like sound that can
070     * exist in walls, or for assigning decor to floors or walls that are adjacent to floors.
071     * @param map
072     * @param start
073     * @param eightWay
074     * @return
075     */
076    public static Point randomStep(char[][] map, Point start, boolean eightWay)
077    {
078        int width = map.length;
079        int height = map[0].length;
080        if(width < 3 || height < 3 || start.x <= 0 || start.y <= 0 || start.x >= width - 1 || start.y >= height - 1)
081            return null;
082        Point stepped = new Point(start.x, start.y);
083
084        if(eightWay)
085        {
086            int mv = rng.nextInt(9);
087            stepped.translate((mv % 3) - 1, (mv / 3) - 1);
088        }
089        else
090        {
091            int mv = rng.nextInt(5);
092            switch (mv)
093            {
094                case 0: stepped.translate(-1, 0);
095                    break;
096                case 1: stepped.translate(1, 0);
097                    break;
098                case 2: stepped.translate(0, -1);
099                    break;
100                case 3: stepped.translate(0, 1);
101                    break;
102            }
103        }
104        return stepped;
105    }
106    /**
107     * Finds a random java.awt.Point where the x and y match up to a [x][y] location on map that has '.' as a value,
108     * and a square of cells extending in the positive x and y directions with a side length of size must also have
109     * '.' as their values.
110     * Uses this class' rng field for pseudo-random number generation.
111     * @param map
112     * @param size
113     * @return a Point that corresponds to a '.' in map, or null if a '.' cannot be found or if map is too small.
114     */
115    public static Point randomFloorLarge(char[][] map, int size)
116    {
117        int width = map.length;
118        int height = map[0].length;
119        if(width < 4 || height < 4)
120            return null;
121        Point pt = new Point(rng.nextInt(width - size), rng.nextInt(height - size));
122        CELL:
123        for(int i = 0; i < 20; i++, pt.x = rng.nextInt(width - size), pt.y = rng.nextInt(height - size))
124        {
125            if(map[pt.x][pt.y] == '.')
126            {
127                for(int x = 0; x < size; x++)
128                {
129                    for(int y = 0; y < size; y++)
130                    {
131                        if(map[pt.x + x][pt.y + y] != '.')
132                            continue CELL;
133                    }
134                }
135                return pt;
136            }
137        }
138        pt.x = 1;
139        pt.y = 1;
140
141        SLOW:
142        while(true)
143        {
144            pt.x += 1;
145            if(pt.x >= width - size)
146            {
147                pt.x = 1;
148                pt.y += 1;
149            }
150            if(pt.y >= height - size)
151                return null;
152            if(map[pt.x][pt.y] == '.')
153            {
154                for(int x = 0; x < size; x++)
155                {
156                    for(int y = 0; y < size; y++)
157                    {
158                        if(map[pt.x + x][pt.y + y] != '.')
159                            continue SLOW;
160                    }
161                }
162                return pt;
163            }
164        }
165    }
166
167    /**
168     * Takes a char[][] dungeon map that uses '#' to represent walls, and returns a new char[][] that uses unicode box
169     * drawing characters to draw straight, continuous lines for walls, filling regions between walls (that were
170     * filled with more walls before) with space characters, ' '. If the lines "point the wrong way," such as having
171     * multiple horizontally adjacent vertical lines where there should be horizontal lines, call transposeLines() on
172     * the returned map, which will keep the dimensions of the map the same and only change the line chars. You will
173     * also need to call transposeLines if you call hashesToLines on a map that already has "correct" line-drawing
174     * characters, which means hashesToLines should only be called on maps that use '#' for walls. If you have a
175     * jumbled map that contains two or more of the following: "correct" line-drawing characters, "incorrect"
176     * line-drawing characters, and '#' characters for walls, you can reset by calling linesToHashes() and then
177     * potentially calling hashesToLines() again.
178     * @param map
179     * @return
180     */
181    public static char[][] hashesToLines(char[][] map)
182    {
183        int width = map[0].length+2;
184        int height = map.length+2;
185
186        char[][] neo = new char[height][width], dungeon = new char[height][width];
187        for(int i = 1; i < height - 1; i++)
188        {
189            for(int j = 1; j < width - 1; j++)
190            {
191                dungeon[i][j] = map[i-1][j-1];
192            }
193        }
194        for(int i = 0; i < height; i++)
195        {
196            neo[i][0] = '\1';
197            neo[i][width-1] = '\1';
198            dungeon[i][0] = '\1';
199            dungeon[i][width-1] = '\1';
200        }
201        for(int i = 0; i < width; i++)
202        {
203            neo[0][i] = '\1';
204            neo[height-1][i] = '\1';
205            dungeon[0][i] = '\1';
206            dungeon[height-1][i] = '\1';
207        }
208
209        for (int y = 1; y < height - 1; y++)
210        {
211            for (int x = 1; x < width - 1; x++)
212            {
213                if (map[y-1][x-1] == '#')
214                {
215                    int q = 0;
216                    q |= (y <= 1 || map[y - 2][x-1] == '#') ? 1 : 0;
217                    q |= (y <= 1 || x >= width - 2 || map[y - 2][x + 0] == '#') ? 2 : 0;
218                    q |= (x >= width - 2  || map[y - 1][x + 0] == '#') ? 4 : 0;
219                    q |= (y >= height - 2 || x >= width - 2 || map[y + 0][x + 0] == '#') ? 8 : 0;
220                    q |= (y >= height - 2 || map[y + 0][x-1] == '#') ? 16 : 0;
221                    q |= (y >= height - 2 || x <= 1 || map[y + 0][x - 2] == '#') ? 32 : 0;
222                    q |= (x <= 1 || map[y - 1][x - 2] == '#') ? 64 : 0;
223                    q |= (y <= 1 || x <= 1 || map[y - 2][x - 2] == '#') ? 128 : 0;
224
225                    if (q == 0xff)
226                    {
227                        neo[y][x] = '\1';
228                        dungeon[y][x] = '\1';
229                    }
230                    else
231                    {
232                        neo[y][x] = '#';
233                    }
234                }
235                else
236                {
237                    neo[y][x] = dungeon[y][x];
238                }
239            }
240        }
241
242        for (int y = 0; y < height; y++)
243        {
244            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++)
245            {
246                if (dungeon[y][x] == '#')
247                {
248                    boolean n = (y <= 0 || dungeon[y - 1][x] == '#' || dungeon[y - 1][x] == '+' || dungeon[y - 1][x] == '/');
249                    boolean e = (x >= width - 1 || dungeon[y][x + 1] == '#' || dungeon[y][x + 1] == '+' || dungeon[y][x + 1] == '/');
250                    boolean s = (y >= height - 1 || dungeon[y + 1][x] == '#' || dungeon[y + 1][x] == '+' || dungeon[y + 1][x] == '/');
251                    boolean w = (x <= 0 || dungeon[y][x - 1] == '#' || dungeon[y][x - 1] == '+' || dungeon[y][x - 1] == '/');
252
253                    if (n)
254                    {
255                        if (e)
256                        {
257                            if (s)
258                            {
259                                if (w)
260                                {
261                                    neo[y][x] = '┼';
262                                }
263                                else
264                                {
265                                    neo[y][x] = '├';
266                                }
267                            }
268                            else if (w)
269                            {
270                                neo[y][x] = '┴';
271                            }
272                            else
273                            {
274                                neo[y][x] = '└';
275                            }
276                        }
277                        else if (s)
278                        {
279                            if (w)
280                            {
281                                neo[y][x] = '┤';
282                            }
283                            else
284                            {
285                                neo[y][x] = '│';
286                            }
287                        }
288                        else if (w)
289                        {
290                            neo[y][x] = '┘';
291                        }
292                        else
293                        {
294                            neo[y][x] = '│';
295                        }
296                    }
297                    else if (e)  // ┼ ├ ┤ ┴ ┬ ┌ ┐ └ ┘ │ ─
298                    {
299                        if (s)
300                        {
301                            if (w)
302                            {
303                                neo[y][x] = '┬';
304                            }
305                            else
306                            {
307                                neo[y][x] = '┌';
308                            }
309                        }
310                        else if (w)
311                        {
312                            neo[y][x] = '─';
313                        }
314                        else
315                        {
316                            neo[y][x] = '─';
317                        }
318                    }
319                    else if (s)
320                    {
321                        if (w)
322                        {
323                            neo[y][x] = '┐';
324                        }
325                        else
326                        {
327                            neo[y][x] = '│';
328                        }
329                    }
330                    else if (w)
331                    {
332                        neo[y][x] = '─';
333                    }
334                    else
335                    {
336                        neo[y][x] = '─';
337                    }
338
339                }
340                else
341                {
342                    neo[y][x] = dungeon[y][x];
343                }
344            }
345        }
346        //vertical crossbar removal
347        for (int y = 1; y < height; y++)
348        {
349            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++)
350            {
351                // ┼ ├ ┤ ┴ ┬ ┌ ┐ └ ┘ │ ─
352                if (neo[y][x] == '┼' || neo[y][x] == '├' || neo[y][x] == '┤' || neo[y][x] == '┴')
353                {
354                    if (neo[y - 1][x] == '┼' || neo[y - 1][x] == '├' || neo[y - 1][x] == '┤' || neo[y - 1][x] == '┬')
355                    {
356                        if ((x >= width - 1 || dungeon[y - 1][x + 1] == '#' || dungeon[y - 1][x + 1] == '\1' || dungeon[y - 1][x + 1] == '+' || dungeon[y - 1][x + 1] == '/') &&
357                                (x <= 0 || dungeon[y - 1][x - 1] == '#' || dungeon[y - 1][x - 1] == '\1' || dungeon[y - 1][x - 1] == '+' || dungeon[y - 1][x - 1] == '/') &&
358                                (x >= width - 1 || dungeon[y][x + 1] == '#' || dungeon[y][x + 1] == '\1' || dungeon[y][x + 1] == '+' || dungeon[y][x + 1] == '/') &&
359                                (x <= 0 || dungeon[y][x - 1] == '#' || dungeon[y][x - 1] == '\1' || dungeon[y][x - 1] == '+' || dungeon[y][x - 1] == '/'))
360                        {
361                            switch (neo[y][x])
362                            {
363                                case '┼':
364                                    neo[y][x] = '┬';
365                                    break;
366                                case '├':
367                                    neo[y][x] = '┌';
368                                    break;
369                                case '┤':
370                                    neo[y][x] = '┐';
371                                    break;
372                                case '┴':
373                                    neo[y][x] = '─';
374                                    break;
375                            }
376                            switch (neo[y - 1][x])
377                            {
378                                case '┼':
379                                    neo[y - 1][x] = '┴';
380                                    break;
381                                case '├':
382                                    neo[y - 1][x] = '└';
383                                    break;
384                                case '┤':
385                                    neo[y - 1][x] = '┘';
386                                    break;
387                                case '┬':
388                                    neo[y - 1][x] = '─';
389                                    break;
390
391                            }
392                        }
393                    }
394                }
395            }
396        }
397        //horizontal crossbar removal
398        for (int y = 0; y < height; y++)
399        {
400            for (int x = 1; x < width; x++)
401            {
402                // ┼ ├ ┤ ┴ ┬ ┌ ┐ └ ┘ │ ─
403                if (neo[y][x] == '┼' || neo[y][x] == '┤' || neo[y][x] == '┬' || neo[y][x] == '┴')
404                {
405                    if (neo[y][x - 1] == '┼' || neo[y][x - 1] == '├' || neo[y][x - 1] == '┬' || neo[y][x - 1] == '┴')
406                    {
407                        if ((y >= height - 1 || dungeon[y + 1][x - 1] == '#' || dungeon[y + 1][x - 1] == '\1' || dungeon[y + 1][x - 1] == '+' || dungeon[y + 1][x - 1] == '/') &&
408                                (y <= 0 || dungeon[y - 1][x - 1] == '#' || dungeon[y - 1][x - 1] == '\1' || dungeon[y - 1][x - 1] == '+' || dungeon[y - 1][x - 1] == '/') &&
409                                (y >= height - 1 || dungeon[y + 1][x] == '#' || dungeon[y + 1][x] == '\1' || dungeon[y + 1][x] == '+' || dungeon[y + 1][x] == '/') &&
410                                (y <= 0 || dungeon[y - 1][x] == '#' || dungeon[y - 1][x] == '\1' || dungeon[y - 1][x] == '+' || dungeon[y - 1][x] == '/'))
411                        {
412                            switch (neo[y][x])
413                            {
414                                case '┼':
415                                    neo[y][x] = '├';
416                                    break;
417                                case '┤':
418                                    neo[y][x] = '│';
419                                    break;
420                                case '┬':
421                                    neo[y][x] = '┌';
422                                    break;
423                                case '┴':
424                                    neo[y][x] = '└';
425                                    break;
426                            }
427                            switch (neo[y][x - 1])
428                            {
429                                case '┼':
430                                    neo[y][x - 1] = '┤';
431                                    break;
432                                case '├':
433                                    neo[y][x - 1] = '│';
434                                    break;
435                                case '┬':
436                                    neo[y][x - 1] = '┐';
437                                    break;
438                                case '┴':
439                                    neo[y][x - 1] = '┘';
440                                    break;
441
442                            }
443                        }
444                    }
445                }
446            }
447        }
448        char[][] portion = new char[height-2][width-2];
449        for(int i = 1; i < height - 1; i++)
450        {
451            for(int j = 1; j < width - 1; j++)
452            {
453                switch (neo[i][j])
454                {
455                    case '\1':
456                        portion[i - 1][j - 1] = ' ';
457                        break;
458                    default: // ┼┌┘
459                        portion[i - 1][j - 1] = neo[i][j];
460                }
461            }
462        }
463        return transposeLines(portion);
464    }
465
466    /**
467     * Reverses most of the effects of hashesToLines(). The only things that will not be reversed are the placement of
468     * space characters in unreachable wall-cells-behind-wall-cells, which remain as spaces. This is useful if you
469     * have a modified map that contains wall characters of conflicting varieties, as described in hashesToLines().
470     * @param map
471     * @return
472     */
473    public static char[][] linesToHashes(char[][] map)
474    {
475
476        int width = map.length;
477        int height = map[0].length;
478        char[][] portion = new char[width][height];
479        for(int i = 0; i < width; i++)
480        {
481            for(int j = 0; j < height; j++)
482            {
483                switch (map[i][j])
484                {
485                    case '\1':
486                    case '├':
487                    case '┤':
488                    case '┴':
489                    case '┬':
490                    case '┌':
491                    case '┐':
492                    case '└':
493                    case '┘':
494                    case '│':
495                    case '─':
496                    case '┼':
497                        portion[i][j] = '#';
498                        break;
499                    default:
500                        portion[i][j] = map[i][j];
501                }
502            }
503        }
504        return portion;
505    }
506    /**
507     * If you call hashesToLines() on a map that uses [y][x] conventions instead of [x][y], it will have the lines not
508     * connect as you expect. Use this function to change the directions of the box-drawing characters only, without
509     * altering the dimensions in any way. This returns a new char[][], instead of modifying the parameter in place.
510     * transposeLines is also needed if the lines in a map have become transposed when they were already correct;
511     * calling this method on an incorrectly transposed map will change the directions on all of its lines.
512     * @param map
513     * @return
514     */
515    public static char[][] transposeLines(char[][] map)
516    {
517
518        int width = map[0].length;
519        int height = map.length;
520        char[][] portion = new char[height][width];
521        for(int i = 0; i < height; i++)
522        {
523            for(int j = 0; j < width; j++)
524            {
525                switch (map[i][j])
526                {
527                    case '\1':
528                        portion[i][j] = ' ';
529                        break;
530                    case '├':
531                        portion[i][j] = '┬';
532                        break;
533                    case '┤':
534                        portion[i][j] = '┴';
535                        break;
536                    case '┴':
537                        portion[i][j] = '┤';
538                        break;
539                    case '┬':
540                        portion[i][j] = '├';
541                        break;
542                    case '┐':
543                        portion[i][j] = '└';
544                        break;
545                    case '└':
546                        portion[i][j] = '┐';
547                        break;
548                    case '│':
549                        portion[i][j] = '─';
550                        break;
551                    case '─':
552                        portion[i][j] = '│';
553                        break;
554//                    case '├ ┤ ┴ ┬ ┌ ┐ └ ┘ │ ─':
555                    default: // ┼┌┘
556                        portion[i][j] = map[i][j];
557                }
558            }
559        }
560        return portion;
561    }
562
563    /**
564     * When a map is generated by DungeonGenerator with addDoors enabled, different chars are used for vertical and
565     * horizontal doors ('+' for vertical and '/' for horizontal).  This makes all doors '+', which is useful if you
566     * want '/' to be used for a different purpose and/or to distinguish open and closed doors.
567     * @param map
568     * @return
569     */
570    public static char[][] closeDoors(char[][] map)
571    {
572
573        int width = map.length;
574        int height = map[0].length;
575        char[][] portion = new char[width][height];
576        for(int i = 0; i < width; i++)
577        {
578            for(int j = 0; j < height; j++)
579            {
580                if(map[i][j] == '/') portion[i][j] = '+';
581                else portion[i][j] = map[i][j];
582
583            }
584        }
585        return portion;
586    }
587
588    /**
589     * Takes a dungeon map with either '#' as the only wall character or the unicode box drawing characters used by
590     * hashesToLines(), and returns a new char[][] dungeon map with two characters per cell, mostly filling the spaces
591     * next to non-walls with space characters, and only doing anything different if a box-drawing character would
592     * continue into an adjacent cell, or if a '#' wall needs another '#' wall next to it. The recommended approach is
593     * to keep both the original non-double-width map and the newly-returned double-width map, since the single-width
594     * maps can be used more easily for pathfinding. If you need to undo this function, call unDoublewidth().
595     * @param map
596     * @return
597     */
598    public static char[][] doubleWidth(char[][] map)
599    {
600        int width = map.length;
601        int height = map[0].length;
602        char[][] paired = new char[width*2][height];
603        for (int y = 0; y < height; y++)
604        {
605            for (int x = 0, px = 0; x < width; x++, px += 2)
606            {
607                paired[px][y] = map[x][y];
608                switch (paired[px][y])
609                {
610                    //                        case '┼ ├ ┤ ┴ ┬ ┌ ┐ └ ┘ │ ─'
611                    case '┼':
612                    case '├':
613                    case '┴':
614                    case '┬':
615                    case '┌':
616                    case '└':
617                    case '─':
618                        paired[px + 1][y] = '─';
619                        break;
620                    case '#':
621                        paired[px + 1][y] = '#';
622                        break;
623
624                    default:
625                        paired[px + 1][y] = ' ';
626                        break;
627                        /*
628                    case '.':
629                    case '┤':
630                    case '┐':
631                    case '┘':
632                    case '│':
633                         */
634                }
635            }
636        }
637        return paired;
638    }
639
640    /**
641     * Takes a dungeon map that uses two characters per cell, and condenses it to use only the left (lower index)
642     * character in each cell. This should (probably) only be called on the result of doubleWidth(), and will throw an
643     * exception if called on a map with an odd number of characters for width, such as "#...#" .
644     * @param map
645     * @return
646     */
647    public static char[][] unDoublewidth(char[][] map)
648    {
649        int width = map.length;
650        int height = map[0].length;
651        if(width % 2 != 0)
652            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Argument must be a char[width][height] with an even width.");
653        char[][] unpaired = new char[width/2][height];
654        for (int y = 0; y < height; y++)
655        {
656            for (int x = 0, px = 0; px < width; x++, px += 2)
657            {
658                unpaired[x][y] = map[px][y];
659            }
660        }
661        return unpaired;
662    }
663
664    /**
665     * Produces an int[][] that can be used with any palette of your choice for methods in SquidPanel or for your own
666     * rendering method. 1 is used as a default and for tiles with nothing in them; if the background is black, then
667     * white would make sense as this default. Other indices used are 2 for walls (this doesn't care if the walls are
668     * hashes or lines), 3 for floors (usually '.'), 4 for doors ('+' and '/' in the map), 5 for water, and 6 for traps.
669     * @param map
670     * @return
671     */
672    public static int[][] generatePaletteIndices(char[][] map)
673    {
674
675        int width = map.length;
676        int height = map[0].length;
677        int[][] portion = new int[width][height];
678        for(int i = 0; i < width; i++)
679        {
680            for(int j = 0; j < height; j++)
681            {
682                switch (map[i][j])
683                {
684                    case '\1':
685                    case '├':
686                    case '┤':
687                    case '┴':
688                    case '┬':
689                    case '┌':
690                    case '┐':
691                    case '└':
692                    case '┘':
693                    case '│':
694                    case '─':
695                    case '┼':
696                    case '#':
697                        portion[i][j] = 2;
698                        break;
699                    case '.':
700                        portion[i][j] = 3;
701                        break;
702                    case '+':
703                    case '/':
704                        portion[i][j] = 4;
705                        break;
706                    case '~':
707                        portion[i][j] = 5;
708                        break;
709                    case '^':
710                        portion[i][j] = 6;
711                        break;
712                    default:
713                        portion[i][j] = 1;
714                }
715            }
716        }
717        return portion;
718    }
719    /**
720     * Produces an int[][] that can be used with any palette of your choice for methods in SquidPanel or for your own
721     * rendering method, but meant for the background palette. This will produce 0 for anything but water (represented
722     * by '~'), and will produce 24 for water backgrounds (in the default palette, this is dark blue-green).
723     * @param map
724     * @return
725     */
726    public static int[][] generateBGPaletteIndices(char[][] map)
727    {
728
729        int width = map.length;
730        int height = map[0].length;
731        int[][] portion = new int[width][height];
732        for(int i = 0; i < width; i++)
733        {
734            for(int j = 0; j < height; j++)
735            {
736                switch (map[i][j])
737                {
738                    case '\1':
739                    case '├':
740                    case '┤':
741                    case '┴':
742                    case '┬':
743                    case '┌':
744                    case '┐':
745                    case '└':
746                    case '┘':
747                    case '│':
748                    case '─':
749                    case '┼':
750                    case '#':
751                        portion[i][j] = 0;
752                        break;
753                    case '.':
754                        portion[i][j] = 0;
755                        break;
756                    case '+':
757                    case '/':
758                        portion[i][j] = 0;
759                        break;
760                    case '~':
761                        portion[i][j] = 24;
762                        break;
763                    case '^':
764                        portion[i][j] = 0;
765                        break;
766                    default:
767                        portion[i][j] = 0;
768                }
769            }
770        }
771        return portion;
772    }
773    /**
774     * Produces an int[][] that can be used with SquidLayers to alter the background colors.
775     * @param map
776     * @return
777     */
778    public static int[][] generateLightnessModifiers(char[][] map)
779    {
780        int width = map.length;
781        int height = map[0].length;
782        int[][] portion = new int[width][height];
783        for(int i = 0; i < width; i++)
784        {
785            for(int j = 0; j < height; j++)
786            {
787                switch (map[i][j])
788                {
789                    case '\1':
790                    case '├':
791                    case '┤':
792                    case '┴':
793                    case '┬':
794                    case '┌':
795                    case '┐':
796                    case '└':
797                    case '┘':
798                    case '│':
799                    case '─':
800                    case '┼':
801                    case '#':
802                        portion[i][j] = 0;
803                        break;
804                    case '.':
805                        portion[i][j] = 20;
806                        break;
807                    case '+':
808                    case '/':
809                        portion[i][j] = -20;
810                        break;
811                    case '~':
812                        portion[i][j] = (int)(100 * (PerlinNoise.noise(i / 4.0, j / 4.0) / 2.5 - 0.65));
813                        break;
814                    case '^':
815                        portion[i][j] = 40;
816                        break;
817                    default:
818                        portion[i][j] = 0;
819                }
820            }
821        }
822        return portion;
823    }
824    /**
825     * Produces an int[][] that can be used with SquidLayers to alter the background colors, accepting a parameter for
826     * animation frame if rippling water using Perlin Noise is desired.
827     * @param map
828     * @param frame
829     * @return
830     */
831    public static int[][] generateLightnessModifiers(char[][] map, double frame)
832    {
833        int width = map.length;
834        int height = map[0].length;
835        int[][] portion = new int[width][height];
836        for(int i = 0; i < width; i++)
837        {
838            for(int j = 0; j < height; j++)
839            {
840                switch (map[i][j])
841                {
842                    case '\1':
843                    case '├':
844                    case '┤':
845                    case '┴':
846                    case '┬':
847                    case '┌':
848                    case '┐':
849                    case '└':
850                    case '┘':
851                    case '│':
852                    case '─':
853                    case '┼':
854                    case '#':
855                        portion[i][j] = 30;
856                        break;
857                    case '.':
858                        portion[i][j] = 0;
859                        break;
860                    case '+':
861                    case '/':
862                        portion[i][j] = -20;
863                        break;
864                    case '~':
865                        portion[i][j] = (int)(100 * (PerlinNoise.noise(i / 4.0, j / 4.0, frame / 25.0) / 2.5 - 0.65));
866                        break;
867                    case '^':
868                        portion[i][j] = 40;
869                        break;
870                    default:
871                        portion[i][j] = 0;
872                }
873            }
874        }
875        return portion;
876    }
877    /**
878     * Given a char[][] for the map, produces a double[][] that can be used with FOV.calculateFOV(). It expects any
879     * doors to be represented by '+' if closed or '/' if open (which can be caused by calling
880     * DungeonUtility.closeDoors() ), any walls to be '#' or line drawing characters, and it doesn't care what other
881     * chars are used (only doors, including open ones, and walls obscure light and thus have a resistance by default).
882     * @param map a dungeon, width by height, with any closed doors as '+' and open doors as '/' as per closeDoors()
883     * @return a resistance map suitable for use with the FOV class
884     */
885    public static double[][] generateResistances(char[][] map)
886    {
887        int width = map.length;
888        int height = map[0].length;
889        double[][] portion = new double[width][height];
890        for(int i = 0; i < width; i++)
891        {
892            for(int j = 0; j < height; j++)
893            {
894                switch (map[i][j])
895                {
896                    case '\1':
897                    case '├':
898                    case '┤':
899                    case '┴':
900                    case '┬':
901                    case '┌':
902                    case '┐':
903                    case '└':
904                    case '┘':
905                    case '│':
906                    case '─':
907                    case '┼':
908                    case '#':
909                        portion[i][j] = 1.0;
910                        break;
911                    case '.':
912                        portion[i][j] = 0.0;
913                        break;
914                    case '/':
915                        portion[i][j] = 0.15;
916                        break;
917                    case '+':
918                        portion[i][j] = 0.95;
919                        break;
920                    case '~':
921                        portion[i][j] = 0.0;
922                        break;
923                    case '^':
924                        portion[i][j] = 0.0;
925                        break;
926                    default:
927                        portion[i][j] = 0.0;
928                }
929            }
930        }
931        return portion;
932    }
933}
